M: Hello, Miss Smith. This is Henry. How are you there in Australia?

W: I’m fine. Yesterday I gave you a call but you happened to be out on business.

M: Yes. My secretary said you wanted to tell me something important. What is it?

W: It’s a report from the marketing research office.

M: Will you send me an e-mail copy today? I’ll discuss it with you later.

W: All right. By the way, I’ll go to America on company business tomorrow and I’ll be staying for two days.

M: Then please call me as soon as you get back, will you? You know, I’ve been busy these days. The sales have been down by one third.

W: Sorry to hear that and I hope you’ll soon find a good way to solve it.

M: Thank you.

W: Hi, Chris. I hear Lynne’s back. I thought she was coming on Saturday.

M: Yeah, actually she came home on Wednesday.

W: Really? How is her new job with that computer company?

M: Great. Now she’s in New York for a year. Next year she’ll go to Hong Kong! And she gets four weeks’ holiday a year. Next year it’ll be six — my dad only gets five!

W: That’s great! I’d like to work with computers.

M: Me too, but Lynne didn’t study anything with computers at school. Dad taught her at home and then she did maths at university.

W: She must work hard. Can I see her tomorrow?

M: Of course. Come in the afternoon. She’ll be in bed all morning.

W: OK, I’ll come after lunch. I’ve bought her a watch for her birthday.

M: She really wanted me to get her a camera but I only had enough money for a computer game.

W: I’m sure she’ll like it.

M: Good afternoon. Where are you heading?

W: It’s the ... er ... Caledonian Hotel, please. It’s in Princess Street.

M: Caledonian Hotel, I know it, all right. Please wear your seat belt. So are you here on holiday?

W: Yeah. I’m here on holiday. How did you know?

M: Oh, I can always tell. Where are you from? America, is it?

W: No, I’m Canadian. I’m from Toronto.

M: Canada? Well, that’s a long way to come. Is this your first time in Edinburgh?

W: Yes, it’s my first time here, but I have family here.

M: Is that right?

W: Mr. Ford’s office. May I help you?

M: Hello. This is Alan Huesing. You know, I planned to meet Mr. Ford at noon.

W: Oh, yes, Mr. Huesing. Is there something wrong?

M: Yes, I started driving toward your company this morning, but somehow I ended up on the opposite side of the city. It’s already 11:45 and I don’t think I can make it by noon.

W: Oh, that’s too bad. It’ll take at least an hour to get back into town.

M: Is it all right if I come in that late?

W: I’m afraid not, because Mr. Ford will attend an important meeting at 1:30. Mr. Huesing, let’s see, how about tomorrow morning?

M: That’s all right with me. I am terribly sorry and please give my apologies to Mr. Ford.

W: Sure, I will. Please drive carefully into a new town next time.

M: I will, thank you. Goodbye.

W: Hello, Ryan. Thanks so much for the goodbye party! It was a big surprise and I really enjoyed it. I’m sorry I had to leave early — Dad was worried about the traffic. In the end, we got to the airport much too early. Then the flight was three hours late. We felt really bored and I slept for a short while. My sister did some shopping in the duty-free shops. My mum isn’t used to flying, so she was quite nervous. In order to make herself feel better, she listened to some music. Anyway, altogether it wasn’t much fun. Fortunately, New York time is five hours behind London, so it was still Sunday evening when we arrived.

 New York is really different from London, and I feel quite strange. I guess I’ll need a few days to get used to it. And fortunately, the locals are friendly. Yesterday my cousin Sam and I went to Fifth Avenue. You’ve probably heard of it — it’s famous for its amazing stores. I was surprised at the prices. Things are much cheaper here. I’m quite tired of travelling now, and I can’t wait to get home to LA! Ryan. Don’t forget to call me back. Bye.

[{"id":11162,"main_id":61359,"questions":1,"subject":"How did the couple order their meal?","answer":"A. By using body language.","answer_a":"A. By using body language.","answer_b":"B. By speaking Chinese slowly.","answer_c":"C. By speaking English.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: This is a true story about a French couple, Paul and Maggie, who had just moved to Hong Kong for a few days and went to a restaurant for a meal. They couldn’t speak Chinese or even English well, so they had to use sign language to order their meal. Well, this seemed to work all right. The waiter nodded and started to go for the kitchen. Oh, I forgot to mention they had their pet dog, Rosa, with them. Maggie reminded her husband that Rosa was hungry. They called the waiter back and they pointed at Rosa and made eating gestures. The waiter looked puzzled. But in the end he smiled and nodded and picked up the dog and took it to the kitchen. After about half an hour the waiter returned with their main course on a silver dish covered with a large silver cover. You’ll never believe this, but it really happened. M: My neck and shoulders are killing me! I can hardly move my neck and my shoulders hurt!

W: Do you use the computer a lot?

M: Yes. I have been staring at the screen for hours. And I use the mouse a lot.

W: How long have you been doing this?

M: Quite a few days. I have been busy with my paper these days. I have to hand it in at next week’s class.

W: Maybe that’s the reason. I read an article about this a few days ago. It says that this is a new kind of illness. People using computers too much will suffer from it.

M: No wonder! So what should I do?

W: Well, the article says that taking a ten-minute break every one hour would be helpful. You could keep moving your head from side to side. You could also move your shoulders for a few minutes.

M: Sounds like a good idea! I’ll try that.

M: Well, Mum, thanks for having Simon stay for a couple of days.

W: That’s OK, Philip. What have I got to do?

M: Well, Saturday’s busy. In the morning he’s got his piano class.

W: Right, and in the afternoon he’s going to a birthday party, isn’t he?

M: No, that’s in the evening. He’s going to the football match in the afternoon, remember?

W: Oh, yes, I remember now. So what time does the party start?

M: At half past seven and Mrs. Carter will bring him home.

W: Fine. Now on Sunday morning, we can go to the swimming pool on our bikes.

M: Well, he’s got a cold, so swimming isn’t a very good idea, but he’d like a bicycle ride.

W: OK. Your father wants to take Simon to the park in the afternoon.

M: Fine. And then a quiet evening watching TV.

W: What about a trip to the cinema?

M: No. I think he’ll be too tired for that.

W: OK.

M: Good morning, boys and girls. Welcome to our university. My name is Jack Brown. I’m an English teacher. I’m glad to be here to tell you something about our university. The sports centre is open from 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Monday to Friday. Look on the noticeboards there for information about swimming, team games and track and field. It is also possible to join some local city clubs if you show your student cards. For example, you can play tennis at a lower price. 

The Musical School welcomes all members of the university. It also offers part-time courses. Why not take the chance to start learning the guitar, violin or piano while you’re here? Many high-level students offer really cheap lessons. There are also open evenings when anyone can take the chance to perform in front of an audience. Look out for notices with times and dates. 

That’s all for me. If you have any other questions, don’t call me or send an e-mail to me. Just go straight to my office to ask me.

[{"id":11281,"main_id":61449,"questions":1,"subject":"What is the relationship between the speakers?","answer":"B. Workmates.","answer_a":"A. Relatives.","answer_b":"B. Workmates.","answer_c":"C. Interviewer and interviewee.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: Hi, you must be the new person. 

W: Yeah, that’s right. I just started on Monday.

M: So, how do you like it here?

W: It’s great, so far. It’s a nice change from my last job.

M: Oh? Where did you work before?

W: I worked at Delta Communications, in marketing. It’s in a small town close to Chicago.

M: Are you from Chicago?

W: Yes, I am. My family still lives there. Have you ever been to Chicago?

M: No, I haven’t. I’m from San Francisco. But I’ve heard it’s really nice, and I’ve heard there are some great museums there, too.

W: Yes, there are. 

M: Well, there are some great art centers here in New York. You should visit them when you have a chance.

W: Great idea. Are you interested in art?

M: Yes, I like going to museums. But I’m even more interested in music, especially jazz and country music. I love going to concerts.

W: So do I! I love pop music.

M: Hi, you must be the new person. 

W: Yeah, that’s right. I just started on Monday.

M: So, how do you like it here?

W: It’s great, so far. It’s a nice change from my last job.

M: Oh? Where did you work before?

W: I worked at Delta Communications, in marketing. It’s in a small town close to Chicago.

M: Are you from Chicago?

W: Yes, I am. My family still lives there. Have you ever been to Chicago?

M: No, I haven’t. I’m from San Francisco. But I’ve heard it’s really nice, and I’ve heard there are some great museums there, too.

W: Yes, there are. 

M: Well, there are some great art centers here in New York. You should visit them when you have a chance.

W: Great idea. Are you interested in art?

M: Yes, I like going to museums. But I’m even more interested in music, especially jazz and country music. I love going to concerts.

W: So do I! I love pop music.

W: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Elwood Food Market. To make sure that you’ll have a good shopping trip, I’ll tell you some information about the market. There are three large food halls here. Now I’ll tell you what products are provided in each hall. Turn left at the entrance for Hall One. Here you can buy many different vegetables. This hall also has very good fish. It all comes here straight from the sea. So the fish is really fresh and delicious. You shouldn’t miss it. In Hall Two, you can find lovely cakes and fish hamburgers. And they are sold at a really right price. Next to this hall there is a café. You can get sandwiches and drinks the whole day in the café and a hot breakfast until 10:30 a.m. Hall Three is the biggest hall and sells cheese, eggs and meat. In this hall there is also a special Italian shop. You can buy different pizza. Children will love our new playroom. It’s at the end of the hall next to the telephones. You can leave them there safely when you shop. We wish you a very good time here!

[{"id":11318,"main_id":61476,"questions":1,"subject":"What does the woman think of buying a mountain bike?","answer":"A. Unnecessary.","answer_a":"A. Unnecessary.","answer_b":"B. Useful.","answer_c":"C. Reasonable.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: Mum, my old bicycle needs to be repaired again.

W: Well then, why don’t you just think of buying a new one?

M: You know, I’d really like to buy one of those mountain bikes. But they cost too much. At least $300. 

W: But what’s so special about a mountain bike? Why do you have to have one of those? There aren’t any mountains around here. Isn’t a common bike cheaper?

M: Yes. You can also get good ones for about $150.

W: Well, that sounds reasonable. If you can save $100, I’ll give you the rest. That way you’ll be riding a new bike in a few months. Go and get your old one repaired.

M: Thanks, Mum. I suppose I’ll just have to ride my old bike for a little longer.

[{"id":11329,"main_id":61480,"questions":1,"subject":"What is the woman’s opinion about the painting Les Demoise de Avignon?","answer":"A. Strange.","answer_a":"A. Strange.","answer_b":"B. Beautiful. ","answer_c":"C. Modern.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: Jack, just come and look at this amazing painting.

M: Well, let me see. Yeah, it is really amazing, but what is it exactly?

W: It’s a Picasso! It looks really strange. Don’t you think so?

M: That’s true. It’s strange but beautiful. What is it called?

W: Let me see ...  this one is Les Demoise de Avignon, and it was painted in 1907.

M: 1907? That’s over one hundred years ago, but this work looks so modern! He’s a great artist.

W: Well, he was born in 1881. And he died when he was 92. It seems that he had a long life.

M: Yeah. I heard that he had many girlfriends, who he often painted. And he had many children.

W: Yes, that’s true. But I think he only married twice. His true love was a lady called Jacqueline, who he married in 1961.

W: Since last week, hundreds of listeners have called the show to say they’re interested in the art classes we talked about. Well, I have some good news for them! There will be more classes at the London College of Art this spring and summer. You can do a course in May, July or August. Each course lasts three weeks and the teacher will be Helen Parkes. 

 Helen has taught art for many years in schools and colleges and is a famous artist herself. You don’t need to bring brushes or paints but you must have a notebook with you to take notes.

[{"id":11450,"main_id":61552,"questions":1,"subject":"Where will the woman go next week?","answer":"A. To Britain. ","answer_a":"A. To Britain. ","answer_b":"B. To the United States.","answer_c":"C. To Australia.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: And today we have a familiar face on television, Angela Bond, the news reporter. Welcome, Angela. Your job has taken you all over the world, hasn’t it?

W: Yes. I’ve reported from a number of countries in Asia and I’ve just returned from the United States, then next week I will go to London.

M: Is the traveling what you enjoy about the job?

W: It’s certainly interesting, but it can be annoying never knowing where I’m going to be next week! For me, the really exciting thing is being somewhere when a big news story is taking place and seeing it develop.

M: Well, do you have much time for a social life?

W: It’s better now. I’m in Sydney and I can see my boyfriend more often. My sister introduced us. We have a lot in common. He’s a lawyer and I studied law at university. Also we found that we lived in Hong Kong at the same time, although we never met.

M: What do you like to do in your free time?

W: Well, cooking is something new I’m trying. And one of the best things I’ve bought recently was a boat and when I want to feel calm and peaceful I’d like to go boating on the river.

M: Are zoos necessary, or are they only bad to the animals? This is a question that causes disagreement among many animal experts. Some, we may just call them Group A, believe that placing animals in a zoo does harm to them. These people think that all animals should be protected from being hunted too much and left in their native land. They also advise people to be educated to know more about animals in the wild. Other experts of Group B think differently. They say that modern zoos are designed very closely to the natural environment. One of their strongest arguments is that certain species, such as the panda from China and the white tiger from India, are not only protected from uncontrolled killing but can give babies under protection and in that way they may be saved from dying out. OK, that’s all from me and you’re expected to express your opinions on this question next class.
